title: SŠ Čichnova trenink def
description: Test your capabilities in the KYPO Cyber Range Platform.

levels.title: Info
levels.content:
# Little summary before you start

This training contains all types of levels to test your capabilities of the KYPO Cyber Range Platform.

| Level | Level Name | Level Type |
|:------:|------| ------ |
| 1. | Info | Info |
| 2. | Finding Open Ports | Training |
| 3. | Connecting via Telnet | Training |
| 4. | Privilege Escalation | Training |
| 5. | Test your knowledge | Assessment |
| 6. | Feedback | Assessment |


## Info about each level:


* 
### Info
You are currently on this level. It contains information about this whole training and what awaits you in next levels.


* 
### Finding open ports
The level will test you on some basic commands. Your goal is to find an open port on server.


* 
### Connecting Via Telnet
This level's challenge is to connect to the server machine without a password and discover the secret answer. Don't worry, you will have a little help there :)


* 
### Privilege Escalation
This level is a little bit bigger challenge and by that we mean you have to gain root privileges and read an answer available only to a root user. Enjoy! 


* 
### Test your knowledge
This level contains a simple test. This test is supposed to additionally test you, your answers and how much you understand this topic.


* 
### Feedback
This level contains a simple questionnaire so we will get some feedback and we will be able to make this training better and better.

levels.title: Finding open ports
levels.content:
Your main goal is to get access to a **server**. There is **telnet** service and it is not running on a default open port. You have to find the **port** on which telnet service is running. Your answer will be a **port number**. 

1. Access **client console CLI** and open it. Your username and password are **kypo**.
2. Find the **port number**. You can use a lot of options how to find the correct port number.
levels.solution:
1. Connect to the client using either of the options.

2. Look for open ports using the command **`nmap server`**. You can see **ssh** running on port **22** and some other service running on port **2323**. This has to be the **telnet** service.

3. Enter **`2323`** as the answer.

hints.title: Tool to find open ports
hints.content: Use **nmap** and if you don't know how to use it, write **`nmap --help`**.

levels.title: Connecting via Telnet
levels.content: Now you have the **port number** and you would like to connect, but you don't have any credentials. Luckily you know that user **`alice`** has a weak password. You might be able to guess it. The answer is in alices home directory. There is a list of common passwords placed in your home directory for your convenience. Try to use a specific tool to get the password. After you get the password, join the server with username and your newly found password. Then search in **`alice`** home directory for the answer.
levels.solution:
1. You know that **alice** has a weak password so you can try a dictionary attack. A list of common passwords is ready in your home directory. One of possible tools to make a password attack is **hydra**. A command to find the password is **`hydra -l alice -P passlist.txt telnet://server:2323`**. This will reveal alices password **`bacon`**.

2. Now you can connect to the server by using **`telnet server 2323`**, entering username **`alice`** and her password **`bacon`**.

3. To read the answer you can use **`cat flag.txt`**. The answer is **`Top_Secret_Flag`**.

hints.title: Hydra
hints.content: Try using Hydra command to get Alices password.

hints.title: Connecting to alice
hints.content: For connecting to alice server you will need to use a command with **telnet port** and **IP Address**.

levels.title: Privilege Escalation
levels.content:
Great! You managed to login to the server as **alice** but there is not much you can do as this user. Can you find a way to become **root**? Try and look into the root directory ;).

One of common privilege escalation attack vectors is badly configured **sudo**. To see what you can use sudo for, use the **`sudo --list`** command.
levels.solution:
1. You can see that the only command you can use sudo on is **` sudo less /home/alice/flag.txt`**. There is not much to see in the flag, but you can run this as **root**. Is there a way to get a shell?

2. There is, all you have to do is enter **`!sh`** while running the **`sudo less /home/alice/flag.txt`** to get a root shell.

3. To get the answer, use **`cd`** to enter the root directory and **`cat flag.txt`** to read the answer. The answer is **`Cant_Guess_This`**.

hints.title: Using the privilege escalation
hints.content: You have probably figured out that you can run **sudo** on a certain **less** command. To get a shell run **`sudo less /home/alice/flag.txt`**, enter the password. Type **`!sh`** to get a root shell.

questions.text: The Telnet service was running on the default port.
What was the name of the text document in which were the passwords stored?
From how many passwords were you guessing with hydra?
Match the IP Addresses with correct devices.

levels.title: Feedback

questions.text: What did you think about this training? Did it help to you or you know everything?

extended_matching_statements.text: You used a lot of time googling??

questions.text: How would you improve this demo?

levels.instructions: Please answer the questions. The last question is voluntary.
